body: So @daxian-dbw is this permanent now, and OK because .NET Standard 2.0 libraries are supposed to "just work" with .Net 4.x ?
According to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/net-standard, v4.6.1 is .Net Std 2.0 compatible.  https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/1152 should resolve this.

What? How are the NuGet libraries going to fix the NuGet libraries?

I mean, I'm literally filing a bug against these Nuget libraries as they're being built, because I can't reference them.  I just tried **beta 3** in `net461` yesterday before I wrote that comment asking for an update.

We don't build powershell for FullCLR on Github now, and the powershell core NuGet packages are targeting .NET Core only. But we will publish a powershell-standard NuGet package which can be used to build multi-targeted assemblies (universal modules). #1152 is the tracking issue.
@Jaykul if you're saying the beta.3 lib from https://powershell.myget.org/feed/powershell-core/package/nuget/Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK isn't working, that is certainly a problem

@SteveL-MSFT I can't make it work, but it could just be that I don't know how. That's happened a few times 😉 To be honest, it may just be a tooling issue -- but I'm as bleeding edge as I can find here! 😁 


I've been working on [a PowerShell kernel for Jupyter](https://github.com/Jaykul/Jupyter-PowerShell), and although it builds fine targeting netcoreapp2.0, if I try to target net461 (or net462), I can't resolve references.

I believe net461 is compatible with netcore20, but not netcoreapp20.  cc @daxian-dbw

I really _hate_ how badly the naming around .Net Core has been mangled, but I don't think there's any such thing as "netcore20" ... did you mean netstandard20?

Are you saying that all these libraries are targeted wrong and should be targeting .netstandard2.0?

In that case (and having done some reading), you're right.

That's what the big fuss was back in May -- Asp.NET was talking about moving to netcoreapp2.0 and _not_ supporting desktop full framework: https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2022#issuecomment-299424990

If you want to avoid double-targeting as before, shared assemblies that go in NuGet packages ought to be compiled to target NetStandard2.0 in order to support full framework

powershell core assemblies cannot target netstandard2.0 because `System.Management.Automation.dll` depends on `System.Reflection.Emit` and `System.Reflection.Emit.ILGeneration` which are not included in netstandard2.0. These packages depend on JIT compiler, and thus are available only on specific runtimes, for example, .NET Core and .NET. `netstandard2.0` are APIs that are going to be supported by multiple runtimes, including Xamarin and Universal App, which don't have a JIT compiler, and hence the dynamic assembly related APIs are not included in netstandard2.0.

#1152 is tracking the effort to create a reference NuGet package that can be referenced by assemblies targeting both .NET and .NET Core runtimes.
What a headache.  In that case, however, I can close this as a dupe (even though it came first, just for the record 😉).
